jobPostingInfo.jobDescription:
Job Details

New ideas are all around us, but only a few will change the world. That’s our focus at JPL. We ask the biggest questions, then search the universe for answers—literally. We build upon ideas that have guided generations, then share our discoveries to inspire generations to come. Your mission—your opportunity—is to seek out the answers that bring us one step closer. If you’re driven to discover, create, and inspire something that lasts a lifetime and beyond, you’re ready for JPL.

Located in Pasadena, California, JPL has a campus-like environment situated on 177 acres in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains and offers a work environment unlike any other: we inspire passion, foster innovation, build collaboration, and reward excellence.

This unique opportunity is part of the Mechanical Systems Engineering, Fabrication and Test Division (Division 35) which engages in research, technology development, and the creation of advanced mechanical, thermal, propulsion, and electronic packaging systems with expertise that spans the full breath of mechanical disciplines and is applied from architectural concept development through operations.

As the Group Supervisor of Biotechnology and Planetary Protection (353N), you will be working for JPL’s Propulsion, Thermal, and Materials Engineering Section (Section 353), which provides leadership and unique world-class expertise in a wide range of technologies and technical discipline areas of chemical and electrical propulsion, thermal, materials, contamination control, analytical chemistry, geochemical instruments, physics-based modeling, and multiphase flow.

Responsibilities

  • Manage all activities regarding staffing and technical approach for a group of scientists, technologists, and engineers whose work is focused on planetary protection planning and implementation, technology development, and related molecular/microbiological research.
  • Coordinate at all management levels, especially with Mars Exploration and Solar System Exploration Directorates, NASA and ESA Planetary Protection Officers and, as appropriate, with other agencies and institutions doing related biotechnology and engineering work.
  • Responsible for three major planetary protection research and implementation laboratories.
  • Provide technical and professional leadership for the planetary protection discipline across JPL, including recruitment and retention of high caliber planetary protection personnel.
  • Responsible for products being delivered to performance, schedule and cost requirements and actively engage line, project and program managers to resolve conflicts.
  • Publish or contribute to publications in refereed scientific journals, and present papers at scientific conferences.
  • Write or contribute to proposals to support research and missions to achieve scientific goals both internal and external to JPL.
  • Interface with project and other line managers in supporting engineering peer reviews and flight project reviews.
  • Must pursue new mission and/or instrument opportunities through advocacy and outreach within the scientific and stakeholder community.
  • Partners with researchers and other personnel in the development of strategic analysis tools, systems, or methodologies for capturing and organizing experimental data.
  • Partners with researchers to develop the communication strategy for scientific findings
  • Oversees the development and delivery of project/program presentations; ensures that presentations follow project/program communication objectives.
  • Applies complete knowledge of industry and/or academic practices and standards in field to accomplish highly complex and critical tasks for institutional technical review teams to solve urgent, short-fuse project-related problems (tiger teams). Serve as team member on internal review boards for proposals and/or subsystems.

Qualifications

  • Requires a Bachelor’s degree in engineering or science or related technical discipline with typically a minimum of 9 years of related experience; Master’s degree in similar disciplines with a minimum of 7 years of related experience; or PhD in similar disciplines with a minimum of 5 years related experience.
  • Wide-ranging experience and advanced knowledge in one or more of the following areas: biotechnology, planetary protection, system engineering, and/or flight hardware development.
  • Extensive understanding and wide application of advanced principles, theories, concepts and techniques in planetary protection research, sterilization technology and implementation or molecular/microbiological research resulting in contributions to the development of new theories and methods.
  • Knowledge of industry and/or academic practices and standards across a range of applications related to planetary protection, molecular/microbiological methodologies and interdisciplinary laboratory research.
  • Experience with technology development, technology readiness levels, and technology infusion.
  • Demonstrated initiative in the area of helping others to achieve their career goals.
  • Commitment to employee career development with solid experience in mentoring and familiarity with career coaching.
  • Demonstrated ability to interact effectively with all levels of management and internal and external customers.
  • Excellent oral and written communication skills.

Desired Skills:

  • Complete knowledge of Laboratory policies and procedures, NASA policies and procedures, and government regulations across a range of applications.
  • Practical experience in engineering or biological problems. Alternatively, strong working experience in the field of spacecraft hardware development or system engineering. Familiarity with planetary protection technologies as they relate to systems engineering or space missions.
  • Experience in working with scientists (especially microbiologists), technologists and engineers.
  • Experience in conducting and directing interdisciplinary laboratory research, i.e., chemistry, microbiology, technology, including oversight and management of modern research labs.
  • Substantial experience planning budgets and estimating cost to accomplish work. Proven ability to develop solutions, which are highly innovative and extend the boundaries of current knowledge.
  • Familiarity with COSPAR policies.
  • Familiarity with NASA's and/or ESA's Planetary Protection policies and requirements.

JPL has a catalog of benefits and perks that span from the traditional to the unique. This includes a variety of health, dental, vision, wellbeing, and retirement plans, paid time off, learning, rideshare, childcare, flexible schedule, parental leave and many more. Our focus is on work-life balance, and living healthy, fulfilling lives as we Dare Mighty Things Together. For benefits eligible positions, benefits are effective the first day of the month coincident with or immediately following the employee’s start date.

For further benefits information click Benefits and Perks
